Node.id: Welcome to Sun America Learning Center
Get Started
Don't Let Time Slip Away

Item.id: People have all sorts of reasons for postponing their retirement savings, but none of them can change the fact that missing even a few of the stock market's best days can make a big difference.
We think you should start saving now, whether you are old or young, wealthy or just getting by.

Node.id: To demonstrate why this is, we'll address the questions we think you might have:

Item.id: What determines a portfolio's performance?
What if I can't afford to save?
Why should I start now, I'm young?
Shouldn't I save for a house first?
What's the point?
I'm near retirement, where I begin?

Node.id: What Determines a Portolio's Performance?

Item.id: As shown in the chart, investors' gains would have been reduced by almost 60 % if they missed the 40 best days of the market.

Node.id: What if I Can't Afford to Save?

Item.id: Saving is a matter of priority, not income.
If you save the very minimal sum of $1.70 a day- you'll have $50 each month to contribute to an automatic investment plan with a mutual fund or to your company's 401 K plan.
Either way, if you the money transferred directly from your checking account or paycheck, you'll never miss it.

Node.id: Why Should I Start Now? I'm Young.

Item.id: Time is the most powerful ally you have in saving for retirement.

For example, suppose you're 25 and you sock away $2000 a year in a tax-deferred IRA until you reach the age of 35. Assuming a 10% rate of return, by the time you turn 60, your money will grow to $401,560.

Node.id: Shouldn't I Save for a House First?

Item.id: Saving for a house is a good idea in theory, but not necessarily in practice.
Investing with a tax-deferred 401 K plan, offered by about half of all employers nationwide, can actually help you to borrow up to 50% of your account value for major purchases, such as a house.
You'll pay interest on the loan, but the bulk of the payment will go right back into your retirement savings account.

Node.id: What's the Point? I'm Near Retirement.

Item.id: If you live as long as the average life expectancy, which is increasing each year, you'll need your savings to last you a long time.
This is all the more reason to consider investments that can provide a steady stream of income.

Node.id: Where Do I Begin?

Item.id: Read through The Learning Center and other trusted sources of information, such as personal-investment magazines.

Node.id: Also, if you don't already have a financial representative, arrange a meeting to consult with one.

Item.id: A financial representative can recommend investments you can use to build your personal Retirement Portfolio.

Node.id: Dollar Cost Averaging

Item.id: If we could predict fluctions in the market with perfect accuracy, investing would be simple- and extraordinary profitable.
We could time our transactions to realize big gain and avoid big losses. Buy low, sell high would be a practicable strategy instead of an elusive goal.
Unfortunately, not even the most experienced investment professionals can predict the market.
Attempting to time investments is at best a risky business.
Nevertheless, there is a proven strategy that can help investors overcome the volatility of the market and sometimes even profit from it.
This strategy is called dollar cost averaging.

Node.id: How Dollar Cost Averaging Works: Consistency is the Key

Item.id: Dollar cost averaging means investing the same amount of money in the same investment at regular intervals- say, each month or each quarter.
While it cannot guarantee a profit nor prevent a loss, this approach ensures that you will buy more shares when share prices are low, fewer shares when share prices are high.
The result is that the average amount you pay for each share- your average cost per share- will always be lower than the average price per share.

Node.id: A Sound Strategy is Falling or Rising Markets
Dollar cost averaging can work to your advantage whether the market is falling or rising. Here's how it works:
Falling Market

Item.id: Let's say you invest $500 each month over a period of six months, and during this period, the market declines steadily.
You buy $500 worth of shares at several different prices. At the end of this six month period, you have invested $3000 and you own 312.5 shares. This makes your average price per share $9.60.
So, how do you benefit?
Clearly, dollar cost averaging can't shield you from a loss when the market declines.
However, it can help to reduce your loss.

Node.id: Rising Market

Item.id: Suppose you invest $500 each month. But, this time the market is rising.
You buy $500 worth of shares at different prices. In the end, you own 252.08 shares, and your average price per share was $12.67.
As you can see, your average share cost is less than the average shae price for the period.

Node.id: Is Dollar cost Averaging Right for you?

Item.id: Dollar cost averaging has been used successfully by many investors.
But it is not for everyone.
It is designed not to produce sudden, dramatic profits but to generate sustained growth over the long term, despite short-term fluctuations of the market.
It is most appropriate for long-term investors who have the discipline to keep investing when the market falls and to resist selling when the market rises.
Above all, you need to be patient and give the strategy an opportunity to work.
You should also consider your ability to continue to invest through periods of falling prices.

Node.id: What a Financial Representative Can Do for You

Item.id: Few people buy or sell a house without the aid of a real estate agent.
A real estate agent's expertise can help you save money and make more informed decisions.
When it comes to investing, the same can be said of financial representatives.

With the myriad of investment products, services, and information flooding the market everyday, it helps to consult with a professional who knows the industry and has experience pairing investments with investors.
Everyone can use good financial advice, not just wealthy people.
In fact, investors on a tight budget can benefit the most from sound advice.
A financial representative's job is to help you determine your financial needs and goals.

Node.id: Estate Planning
Universal Life Insurance: More than Financial Protection for You and Your Family

Item.id: You may thinkof life insurance as only a way to help protect your family against an unexpected death.
However, life insurance can also be an important part of your estate plan.

Node.id: Among its many uses, life insurance can provide several benefits:

Item.id: tax advantages to you and your hiers
an immediate death benefit that avoids the delays and costs of probate
a simple and convenient way to distribute assets to your heirs

Node.id: One of the most popular forms of life insurance now being used in estate planning is universal life insurance.

Item.id: For many retirees who have accumulated more money than they need for their retirement nest egg, universal life offers a way to transfer wealth to heirs free of federal income taxes.

Node.id: What is Universal Life Insurance

Item.id: Universal life insurance is a type of permanent life insurance.

Node.id: There are two basic forms of life insurance:
Term life insurance

Item.id: term insurance provides protection for a specific period of time
generally ranges from 1 to 20 years

Node.id: Permanent life insurance

Item.id: offers lifetime protection
lasts as long as premiums are paid or enough cash value remains to support policy expenses

Node.id: there are 3 types of permanent life insurance:

Item.id: universal life
whole life
variable life
The main difference between a universal life policy and other types of permanent insurance is that it offers greater flexibility to change premium payments or the policy's death benefit amont.

Node.id: How Does Universal Life Work?

Item.id: Like most permanent policies, universal life offers a feature known as cash value. When you pay your premiums, part of your money goes toward paying policy expenses and charges.
The rest is allocated to a cash value account that earns interest.
The interest rate will typically vary over time: however, many policies offer a minimum fixed rate that is guaranteed by the claims-paying ability of the insurer.

In a variable universal life policy, the money in your cash value account can be allocated to a wide variety of investments, including stocks and bonds, that provide greater growth potential but can fluctuate in value based on market conditions.
These variable investment features involve risk of loss to your cash value.

Node.id: How Can Universal Life Contribute to an Estate Plan?

Item.id: Besides replacing the lost income of a wage earner, the death benefit from a universal life policy is generally federal income tax free to your heirs.
In addition to this valuable tax advantage, your heirs receive the death proceeds without having to deal with the hassle and costs of probate.
That means your beneficiearies will have liquid funds that can help them pay any estate taxes, funeral costs, or other miscellaneous expenses that occur at death.
Another attracitve feature is that policy proceeds may be protected from creditors and bankruptcy.

Node.id: Unviersal Life Insurance: Family Protection Plus Tax-efficient Wealth Transfer

Item.id: Universal life offers options and benefits that go beyond financial protection for your family in case you die.

Node.id: Universal life offers benefits to last throughout a lifetime wheather you are:

Item.id: 1. young and seeking a way to maintain your family's standard of living in the event of your death
2. middle-aged and seeking a plicy that can meet your family's changing needs
3. older and seeking a way to transfer wealth free from federal income taxes to your loved ones.
